subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove and today I
thought I'd talk about the legacy of
Aleister Crowley. It was on my mind
because recently there have been
discussions of psychedelics, the
counterculture, the 1970s, Timothy Leary,
who was at one time regarded as the most
dangerous man in America. Well, Aleister
Crowley, for those of you who may not
know, was at one time talked about as the
most evil man in the world. And yet, he's
an important cultural figure. Back in the
1970s, I and many of my friends read his
autobiography. He called it an autohagiography,
in other words the
autobiography of a saint, which is
something of a contradiction in terms, I
think. I'm not aware of the fact that any
saints actually wrote autobiographies. I
could be wrong. They probably did, I think
so. The confessions of St. Augustine -
maybe he modeled it like that.
In some ways there's a parallel between
Crowley and Augustine because Augustine
lived, as I recall, a decadent life as
a youth and then he became a saintly
man, a bishop of the church.
Crowley lived a decadent life throughout.
In fact, one of his biographers claimed
that Crowley's life from start to finish
was completely dedicated to the artistic
philosophy of decadence, which was a
very specific artistic philosophy, sort
of: do everything that is unnatural. Well,
one might say that about Crowley,
in a certain way and ironically, that
makes him a heroic figure. Now, I assume,
of course, that the viewers understand
who Crowley was but that's probably a
mistaken assumption. Just because
in my youth I devoured the writings of
Aleister Crowley, as did many of my
friends, doesn't mean that now, fifty
years later, that the viewing audience
here has any knowledge of the man at all.
He's somewhat forgotten. He died in 1947
and was born in 1875. He lived to the
age of 72. He's mostly known as an
occultist, a person who wrote about magic.
But, he's also known as a person who
advocated free sex early on, and
not just heterosexual sex. He believed
that people should be free to express
themselves sexually in any way they
wished: heterosexual, homosexual,
masturbation. But he went a step further
because he developed sex magic rituals.
He tried to combine sexuality with
ritual magic. This was a major part of
his writings and his practice. In so
doing he felt that the focus of
consciousness generated in the sexual
act, through one pointed focus of
consciousness, particularly in orgasm,
could be used for magical purposes -
and by magical purposes he meant the
manifestation of things that you might
desire through an expression, a pure
expression of your will. He wrote
extensively on the topic of magic.
One of his books is Magick in Theory
and Practice. Another interesting title of
his is Magick without Tears. He was
enormously prolific as a writer.
Early on in his career he joined an
esoteric order that had great influence,
called the Order of the Golden Dawn.
Amongst the other members of the order
were William
Butler Yates, who later won a Nobel Prize
for his poetry. Now, Crowley was also a
poet. Actually, he was a good poet, in his
early years. He thought of himself as
maybe the world's greatest poet. He saw
himself, in a very egotistical way, as
the initiator of a new age. In a
sense, one might say that, maybe
prematurely, but he envisioned that
we were entering into a new Aeon. That's
what he called it, a new Aeon, a new era -
that the prior era was the era of the
great patriarchal religions: Buddhism,
Islam, Christianity, Judaism. Prior to that
era was the era of the great matriarchal
religions, the worship of the Mother
Earth goddess across the Earth. He
saw himself as initiating a new era
based on the dictum: do what thou wilt.
People should be free to follow the
dictates of their own will. Now, that
might seem like pure hedonism and pure
decadence. There are many reasons
why it would seem that way, too, if you
look carefully at Crowley's actual
autobiography. I might mention,
parenthetically, he died as a heroin
addict. Now, I don't know that that was so
much his fault. Heroin was prescribed to
him by a medical doctor because he
encountered many illnesses - syphilis,
gonorrhea, malaria - because he was also an
explorer, a mountain climber. He traveled
the world to many, many exotic locations,
India and China. It's also said he was
a double agent working for the British
and the Germans in both World War I,
I think. Also, I believe, he
intended to continue that activity in
World War II but
he wasn't accepted. He was quite
elderly at that point and ill, I might add.
But, there's so much to be said about
Crowley, actually. I know that he had
a big influence on Timothy Leary.
It's also the case that he designed, in
conjunction with one of his devotees, an
artist lady
Frieda Harris, a beautiful tarot deck.
It's a tarot deck of modern art images
but Crowley elaborated all the ancient
esoteric meanings of it, as well.
It was a deck widely used by people in
my youth. Crowley also advocated the
use of drugs in conjunction with magical
rituals. I have, in previous segments,
talked about my fascination in my youth
with a magical grimoire called The
Sacred Magic of Abramelin. This
was central to Crowley's own magical
spiritual interests. He founded a
practice - sometimes it's referred to as
the OTO, the Ordo Templi Orientis, or
sometimes referred to as Thelema, the
Thelemic religion. But, the idea was,
essentially: follow your own will, do what
you will, don't worry about conventional
mores, don't be constrained by Christian
morality, for example. In that sense, he
was in agreement with Frederick
Nietzsche the philosopher, but maybe
taking it a step further, several. You
could say that he was the archetypal
Tantric practitioner. You could... well, let
me continue, though, because if you read
his writings actually he's saying that
if you get in touch with your own will,
and I think by that he meant your deep
purpose,
your entelechy, I sometimes use that
term, not the will of your ego to enjoy
every kind of decadent pleasure. It gets
confused, but perhaps the will of your
deep spiritual purpose, your will to
become the very best version of yourself.
It seems as if Crowley started out in
that direction. In his early life he was
a poet, he was a mountaineer, a
world-class mountaineer who climbed many
famous mountains. You have a sense of
a man of enormous talent, an enormous
willpower, climbing mountains, mountains
sometimes that no one else had climbed
before, treacherous mountains. But then,
something happened along the way
and you see this very high spirited,
individualistic person exploring
mysticism from a very modern perspective,
trying to find, you know, the scientific
value that might lie in it:
"What are human beings capable of
accomplishing?" gradually descending into
a lifestyle of decadence. As I read
his writings in my youth, I was very
impressed by a lengthy poem he wrote
about how his own first wife, Rose,
descended into insanity. She became an
alcoholic. She is the one who encouraged
him in some of his early magical
explorations but eventually her
decadence was so severe, her mental
illness, her alcoholism was so severe, he
divorced her and the grounds for the
divorce were his own infidelities, of
which there were many. He was
bisexual. He had great passion for his
lovers. He could fall in love
dramatically and powerfully
but then it was short-lived, it didn't
last. The relationships all ended and he
was on to another new one because he had
many disciples. His writings were not
wildly popular in his own day but you
can say now - here we are 70 some years, I
think, after his death and many of his
publications are still in print because
people in the counterculture eat them up.
He was a champion of sexual freedom. He
was a champion of the freedom of people
to express themselves hedonistically
through drugs. He was a pioneer in the
relationship of the occult to drugs
and sex and magical rituals. Now, I have to
say this, it didn't work out so well for
him. He lived much of his life because
he had inherited wealth - his father
owned a brewery and he inherited, I think,
a third of his father's wealth at the
age of 11 when his father died. His
parents were devout Christians, actually,
and I think he rebelled against that
early on. He was sent to Christian
schools and he saw a kind of sadism in
the early Christian education he had
with the Plymouth Brethren. I could
go on and on about Aleister Crowley
because he was actually a big
inspiration to me. In spite of what we
might call his many flaws, you have to
admire the man's hutzpah for breaking
every kind of taboo. In a sense, he
was surely a Tantric practitioner. But as
I say, he died as a heroin addict. I think
he was relatively poor, in fact, poor many
times throughout his life because he
had a habit of always spending more
money than he had. His
habits of travel and spending were
typically financed by his devotees
and disciples. That, you know, that came
and went - didn't work out too well. I
should also say this: amongst his
disciples, amongst the people who were
practitioners of Crowley's style of
magic and the organization that he's
mostly associated with, the OTO, one of
them was Jack Parsons, who ended up as a
founder of CalTech, a rocket scientist.
Interestingly enough, Jack Parsons
also associated in those days with L. Ron
Hubbard, the founder of Scientology. So,
there's a direct link between Crowley
and Scientology and between Crowley
and the modern Space Age,
oddly enough. What does this all
mean for you? What can you gain out
of reflecting on the life of Aleister
Crowley? And I, yes, I could ask you a
couple of questions. How does he strike you?
Is there anything in that life
deserving of emulation? I know, you know,
his ability to challenge and his
willingness to challenge every cultural
more makes him a heroic figure. But, you
know, you have to ask yourself what did
he ever accomplish in his life? What
has come out of it? If you look at a
mystical teacher like Rudolf Steiner you
can see the fruits: the development
of biodynamic farming, the Waldorf
education, the science of eurythmy, the
style of painting. I don't see any of
that coming from Crowley. And yet, I do
feel that, philosophically, he belongs in
the tradition of Nietzsche. He belongs...
certainly there's a link between Crowley
and Leary. So, for me, it's a mixed bag,
ultimately. But, I try to… I try to with
all of the people I end up studying,
thinking, you know, what are the positive
things I can get out of this? I do
tend to emphasize the positive more than
the negative but I don't think that's
necessarily good advice for you. Where do
you stand with regard to such a
controversial figure who was once viewed
as the most evil man in the world? I'll
leave you with that thought.
And once again, thank you for being with
me.
